instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of the improved detection of patients at risk of developing ESRD in exploring the improvement of the Tangri score, and how far can this metric go?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the improved detection of patients at risk of developing ESRD is the C statistic. The C statistic is a measure of the model's ability to discriminate between patients who progress to ESRD and those who do not. In the study, the original Tangri risk equation had a C statistic of 0.863, while the inclusion of NMR features improved the C statistic to 0.875. 

The C statistic ranges from 0 to 1, with a value of 0.5 indicating no discrimination and a value of 1 indicating perfect discrimination. Therefore, the improved model with the NMR features has a C statistic of 0.875, which suggests a good ability to distinguish between patients who will progress to ESRD and those who will not.

instruction: Can proton nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy be considered a superior method compared to traditional methods in improving the detection of patients at risk of developing end-stage renal disease (ESRD)?
Output: Yes, proton nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy can be considered a superior method compared to traditional methods in improving the detection of patients at risk of developing end-stage renal disease (ESRD). In the study mentioned, the inclusion of NMR features by state-of-the-art machine learning methods improved the currently best performing kidney failure risk equation, the Tangri score. The C statistic, which measures the accuracy of the risk equation, increased from 0.863 to 0.875 when NMR features were included. This improvement outperformed the Tangri score in 94 out of 100 subsampling rounds. Therefore, the use of proton NMR-based plasma fingerprinting significantly enhanced the detection of patients at risk of developing ESRD, enabling improved patient treatment.
